name: Folic Acid
description: Folic acid (Vitamin B9) is essential for DNA synthesis, cell division, and red blood cell formation. It is particularly important during pregnancy and supports brain and cardiovascular health.
benefits: Supports the formation of red blood cells and prevents anemia
Crucial during pregnancy to prevent neural tube defects
Aids in DNA and RNA synthesis and cell growth
Helps regulate homocysteine levels and supports heart health
May support mood and cognitive function
specialNotes: Folic acid is the synthetic form, more stable than natural folate. Best absorbed with B12. Excess can mask B12 deficiency symptoms.
synergies: Vitamin B12 – together support red blood cells and DNA synthesis
Iron – folate enhances iron’s role in red blood cell formation
Choline – supports brain development alongside folate
incompatibleWith: Alcohol – interferes with absorption and metabolism
Certain medications like methotrexate
sideEffects: Usually well tolerated
High doses may mask signs of B12 deficiency

name: Vitamin C
description: Vitamin C (ascorbic acid) is a powerful water-soluble antioxidant that supports immune function, collagen synthesis, iron absorption, and protection against oxidative stress.
benefits: Enhances immune response and may shorten the duration of colds
Supports collagen formation for healthy skin, joints, and blood vessels
Acts as a potent antioxidant protecting cells from oxidative damage
Improves absorption of non-heme iron from plant-based foods
Aids in wound healing and connective tissue maintenance
specialNotes: Vitamin C is not stored in the body, so regular intake is necessary. High doses may cause digestive upset but are usually well-tolerated in divided doses.
synergies: Iron – improves non-heme iron absorption
Zinc – combined immune-supportive effects
Collagen – enhances skin and joint benefits
incompatibleWith: High alcohol intake – depletes vitamin C levels
NSAIDs or aspirin – may increase vitamin C excretion
sideEffects: High doses (>2000 mg/day) may cause diarrhea or bloating
May increase risk of kidney stones in sensitive individuals

name: Vitamin D
description: Vitamin D is a fat-soluble vitamin essential for calcium absorption, bone health, immune function, and hormonal balance. It is synthesized in the skin through sun exposure and found in limited food sources.
benefits: Supports calcium and phosphorus absorption for strong bones and teeth
Enhances immune system response and reduces susceptibility to infections
Plays a role in mood regulation and may reduce symptoms of depression
Contributes to muscle strength and balance in the elderly
May help reduce inflammation and support heart health
specialNotes: Many people are deficient due to lack of sun exposure. Best taken with a fat-containing meal to enhance absorption.
synergies: Magnesium – necessary to activate vitamin D in the body
Vitamin K2 – helps direct calcium to the bones
Calcium – works together for bone mineralization
incompatibleWith: High doses of vitamin A – may interfere with vitamin D metabolism
Soft drinks (high phosphorus) – may reduce bone benefits
sideEffects: Toxicity can occur at extremely high doses, causing nausea, weakness, and kidney issues
May cause elevated calcium levels if overused

name: Magnesium
description: Magnesium is an essential mineral involved in over 300 biochemical reactions, including muscle and nerve function, blood glucose regulation, energy production, and bone health.
benefits: Supports muscle relaxation and helps reduce cramps and spasms
Calms the nervous system and supports stress resilience
Assists in energy metabolism and reduces fatigue
Contributes to strong bones and cardiovascular health
Regulates blood sugar levels and supports sleep quality
specialNotes: Magnesium needs increase with physical or mental stress. Some forms (e.g., citrate) may cause loose stools.
synergies: Vitamin D – activates enzymes that depend on magnesium
Calcium – works together for muscle and bone function
Vitamin B6 – enhances magnesium uptake into cells
incompatibleWith: Excess calcium or zinc – may compete for absorption
Antacids or proton pump inhibitors – may reduce absorption
sideEffects: High doses can cause diarrhea (especially citrate form)
Deficiency symptoms include cramps, fatigue, and irritability

name: Zinc
description: Zinc is a trace mineral vital for immune function, wound healing, hormone regulation, skin health, and cellular repair. It also supports taste and smell and DNA synthesis.
benefits: Boosts immune defenses and supports wound healing
Promotes healthy skin and may reduce acne and inflammation
Supports testosterone levels and reproductive health
Improves sense of taste and smell
Plays a critical role in cell division and DNA repair
specialNotes: Zinc is best absorbed on an empty stomach but can cause nausea. Take with a light snack if sensitive.
synergies: Vitamin C – synergistic immune support
Quercetin – may aid zinc transport into cells
Magnesium – complements for hormonal balance
incompatibleWith: Iron and calcium – interfere with absorption
Coffee and tea – reduce bioavailability due to phytates
sideEffects: High doses may cause nausea or vomiting
Long-term excess can lead to copper deficiency

name: Vitamin B12
description: Vitamin B12 (cobalamin) is essential for red blood cell formation, nervous system function, and energy production. It is mainly found in animal products and crucial for DNA synthesis.
benefits: Prevents fatigue and supports red blood cell production
Maintains healthy nerve function and mental clarity
Supports DNA and RNA synthesis and cell division
May help improve mood and reduce cognitive decline
Essential for energy metabolism and methylation processes
specialNotes: Absorption requires intrinsic factor. Vegan users must supplement. B12 injections may be used in cases of malabsorption.
synergies: Folate – together regulate homocysteine and support red blood cells
Vitamin B6 – helps convert B12 into active forms
Iron – supports red blood cell health together
incompatibleWith: Alcohol – interferes with absorption
Metformin or acid blockers – reduce B12 uptake
sideEffects: Usually very safe; excess excreted in urine
High doses may rarely cause acne or mild rash
foodSources: Fortified cereals and plant milks (for vegans)

name: Iron
description: Iron is a vital mineral that supports oxygen transport, energy production, and immune function. It is a key component of hemoglobin in red blood cells and myoglobin in muscles.
benefits: Supports oxygen delivery to tissues and muscles
Prevents and treats iron-deficiency anemia
Improves energy, stamina, and exercise performance
Essential for brain development and cognitive function
Supports immune response and recovery
specialNotes: Heme iron (animal-based) is more bioavailable than non-heme (plant-based). Vitamin C enhances absorption. Take on an empty stomach if tolerated.
synergies: Vitamin C – significantly improves iron absorption
Folic Acid – supports red blood cell production
Copper – helps mobilize iron into red blood cells
incompatibleWith: Calcium and dairy – inhibit absorption
Zinc – competes for absorption if taken together
Tea/coffee – tannins reduce iron uptake
sideEffects: Constipation or gastrointestinal discomfort
Dark stools (harmless)
Nausea when taken without food

name: Calcium
description: Calcium is the most abundant mineral in the body, essential for strong bones and teeth, muscle function, nerve signaling, and blood clotting.
benefits: Builds and maintains strong bones and teeth
Supports muscle contractions and heart rhythm
Regulates nerve signaling and hormone release
Helps prevent osteoporosis and bone loss
Supports healthy blood clotting
specialNotes: Needs magnesium and vitamin D to be absorbed effectively. Split doses for best absorption.
synergies: Vitamin D – increases calcium absorption
Vitamin K2 – directs calcium to bones
Magnesium – balances calcium activity in muscles
incompatibleWith: Iron and zinc – inhibit each other's absorption
High sodium intake – increases calcium excretion
sideEffects: Constipation at high doses
May interfere with absorption of other minerals
Excess may lead to kidney stones

name: Selenium
description: Selenium is a trace mineral with antioxidant properties that supports thyroid function, immune response, and DNA synthesis. It helps neutralize free radicals and inflammation.
benefits: Acts as a powerful antioxidant protecting cells from oxidative stress
Supports healthy thyroid hormone metabolism
Boosts immune function and inflammation control
May improve skin clarity and reduce acne
Contributes to fertility and DNA repair
specialNotes: Only 1–2 Brazil nuts can provide the full daily need. Overuse can lead to selenium toxicity.
synergies: Vitamin E – enhances antioxidant capacity
Iodine – works together for thyroid regulation
Zinc – complements for immune function
incompatibleWith: Heavy metal exposure – may reduce effectiveness
Over-supplementation – toxicity risk
sideEffects: High doses can cause brittle hair/nails and garlic breath odor
Long-term excess may lead to selenosis

name: Vitamin K2
description: Vitamin K2 (menaquinone) is essential for directing calcium into bones and teeth while preventing its accumulation in arteries. It plays a critical role in bone strength and cardiovascular protection.
benefits: Directs calcium into bones and teeth, reducing arterial calcification
Strengthens bone density and may reduce fracture risk
Supports heart health and vascular flexibility
May help balance insulin sensitivity and inflammation
Enhances dental health and mineralization
specialNotes: Works best with vitamin D3 and magnesium. Especially important when supplementing with calcium.
synergies: Vitamin D – enhances calcium transport
Calcium – primary partner in bone building
Magnesium – supports mineral balance
incompatibleWith: Blood thinners (e.g., warfarin) – interacts with clotting factors
Excess vitamin A – may reduce K2 effectiveness
sideEffects: Generally well tolerated
Excess doses may interfere with medications

name: Triphala
description: Ayurvedic healing mixture made from three fruits: Amalaki (Emblica officinalis), Bibhitaki (Terminalia bellirica), and Haritaki (Terminalia chebula). One of the most important remedies in Ayurvedic medicine for rejuvenation, regeneration, and detoxification.
benefits: Supports gut health, digestion, and mild detoxification
Antioxidant and cell-protective properties
Anti-inflammatory effects throughout the body
Aids in weight management and metabolism
Supports immune system function
May improve dental health and reduce plaque
Helps regulate blood sugar and cholesterol levels
Promotes healthy skin and anti-aging effects
specialNotes: Traditionally taken on an empty stomach or 2 hours after meals. Dosage: 2-5g daily (1 teaspoon powder 1-2× daily). Course application: 10 weeks intake, then 2-3 weeks break. Can be taken with warm water, buttermilk, ghee, or honey.
synergies: Warm water – traditional combination for digestion
Honey or Ghee – enhances absorption and palatability
Probiotics – supports gut flora restoration
incompatibleWith: Pregnancy and breastfeeding – only with medical advice
Children – consult doctor first
Blood sugar medications – may have additive effects
Large meals or dairy – reduces effectiveness
sideEffects: Mild stomach discomfort or soft stools initially (detox effect)
Possible allergic reactions to fruit components
Excessive intake may cause diarrhea and electrolyte loss
foodSources: Available as powder, capsules, or decoction

name: OPC (Oligomeric Proanthocyanidins)
description: Plant polyphenols and potent antioxidants derived primarily from grape seed extract or pine bark extract. OPCs protect cells and connective tissue from oxidative stress.
benefits: Strong antioxidant that reduces oxidative stress
Supports skin structure (collagen/elastin) and anti-aging effects
Improves wound healing (topical and systemic)
Vascular stabilizing effects on blood pressure and endothelial function
May stimulate hair growth and follicle health
Anti-inflammatory and immunomodulatory properties
Supports recovery after injuries or surgeries
specialNotes: Typical dosage: 200mg OPC per day. Visible results often require 2-4 months. Best absorbed on an empty stomach. Combine with vitamin C for synergistic effects. Quality products should specify actual OPC content.
synergies: Vitamin C (e.g., acerola) – synergistic antioxidant effects
Vitamin E – enhances antioxidant capacity
Collagen – supports skin and joint benefits
incompatibleWith: Blood thinners (e.g., Warfarin) – may increase anticoagulant effect
Grape allergy – avoid grape seed products, use pine bark instead
Very high-fat meals – may reduce absorption
sideEffects: Rare side effects at typical doses
Occasional mild gastrointestinal discomfort
Consult doctor if taking blood-thinning medications

name: Mumijo (Shilajit)
description: Natural biogenic resin from high mountains (Himalaya, Altai, Caucasus) that forms over centuries from decomposed plant and microorganism residues. Contains fulvic and humic acids, minerals, amino acids, polyphenols, and trace vitamins. Known as the 'Black Gold of the Mountains'.
benefits: Adaptogenic, anti-inflammatory, and regenerative properties
Supports tissue healing, cell regeneration, and wound repair
Strengthens digestive system (gastritis, ulcers, intestinal health)
Immunomodulatory effects and stress resilience
Accelerates bone healing and increases strength and endurance
Neuroprotective and reduces oxidative stress in brain
Increases testosterone, sperm count, and fertility in men
Regulates blood lipid levels and improves antioxidant status
Supports altitude adaptation and oxygen utilization
specialNotes: Dosage: 200-300mg, 2-3× daily before meals, dissolved in warm water or as capsule. Course intake: 20-30 days use, then 10-day break. Children under 14: half dose. High-quality products should contain ~200mg fulvic acids per daily dose.
synergies: Honey – traditional combination, improves taste and synergy
B vitamins – neuroprotective effects
Vitamin C – enhances absorption
Magnesium and Zinc – adequate mineral support
incompatibleWith: Medications – maintain 2-3 hour interval
Coffee or tannin-rich teas – reduce effectiveness
Overheating – destroys fulvic compounds
Low-quality products with heavy metal contamination
sideEffects: Rare: mild stomach irritation or nausea at high doses
Risk of heavy metal contamination with low-quality products
May reduce medication effectiveness if taken together
No serious side effects with lab-tested, high-quality products
foodSources: Not a food source – natural mineral resin collected from rock crevices
Available as purified resin, powder, or capsules
Also used in creams for external application

name: MSM (Methylsulfonylmethane)
description: Organic sulfur compound providing bioavailable sulfur essential for protein synthesis, enzyme function, hormone production, and antioxidant systems like glutathione. Sulfur is vital for numerous biochemical processes.
benefits: Supports joint health and reduces osteoarthritis pain
Anti-inflammatory and pain-relieving properties
Reduces allergy symptoms (hay fever, dust mites)
Promotes healthy skin, hair, and nail growth (collagen and keratin synthesis)
Supports liver detoxification and improves cell permeability
Accelerates muscle recovery and reduces exercise-induced damage
Strengthens immune system through glutathione production
Improves gut health and nutrient absorption
specialNotes: Dosage: 3,000-4,000mg per day, divided into 2 servings (morning and midday). Start with 500-1,000mg and increase gradually. Best taken on an empty stomach 30 minutes before meals. Combine with vitamin C for enhanced absorption. Purity should be ≥99.9%.
synergies: Vitamin C (200-500mg) – improves sulfur absorption and antioxidant effects
Glucosamine and Chondroitin – for joint support
Collagen – for skin and connective tissue health
incompatibleWith: Blood thinners (aspirin, warfarin, heparin) – may enhance effects
Large meals – reduce absorption
Excessive alcohol – reduces detoxification capacity
sideEffects: Initial detox symptoms: fatigue, headaches, skin rashes
High doses (>4g) may cause bloating or loose stools
Reduce dosage and drink plenty of water if symptoms occur
Pregnancy/breastfeeding: consult doctor (≤3g considered safe)
foodSources: Typically supplemented as synthetic MSM is more concentrated

name: AFA Algae (Aphanizomenon flos-aquae)
description: Wild-growing blue-green freshwater algae from Upper Klamath Lake (Oregon, USA). One of the oldest life forms on Earth and among the most nutrient-dense natural sources available. Contains high concentrations of vitamins, minerals, amino acids, chlorophyll, enzymes, and phytonutrients.
benefits: Complete protein source with all 20 amino acids including 8 essential ones
High in vitamin B12 (2-3× more than beef liver) for energy and blood formation
Rich in magnesium, calcium, zinc for muscles, bones, and metabolism
Omega-3 and Omega-6 fatty acids support brain and vascular health
3% chlorophyll content supports oxygen transport and cell regeneration
Enhances detoxification and liver function
Strengthens immune system through antioxidants
Promotes mental clarity, concentration, and awareness
Supports nervous system and neurotransmitter balance
May improve mood stability and emotional balance
specialNotes: Dosage: 1-2g daily (powder or tablets) with water or juice, ideally in morning on an empty stomach. For sensitive stomachs, take with meals. Athletes: 2-3g daily. Children (6+ years): half dose. Cure duration: 2-3 months continuous, optional 1-2 week break.
synergies: Vitamin C – enhances nutrient absorption and protects sensitive compounds
Spirulina or Chlorella – broader nutrient spectrum
MSM or OPC – supports detoxification and cell regeneration
incompatibleWith: Coffee or black tea immediately after – inhibits nutrient absorption
Highly heated foods – destroy sensitive enzymes
Phenylketonuria (PKU) – contains phenylalanine
Consult doctor if taking blood thinners or thyroid medications
sideEffects: Initial detox symptoms: fatigue, skin impurities, or headaches
Reduce dosage and drink plenty of water if detox occurs
No toxic accumulation known as it's a natural food
Not suitable for people with phenylketonuria
foodSources: Wild-harvested from Upper Klamath Lake, Oregon
Available as dried powder or tablets
Harvested in summer and gently dried at low temperatures
